title: Portugal’s Costa gets Madeira boost ahead of election
text:
LISBON – Campaigning for Portugal’s general election kicked off Monday with Prime Minister António Costa enjoying big poll leads and boosted by a surge in support for his Socialist Party in a key regional election on the island of Madeira.

The Socialists (PS) more than tripled their score on the traditionally conservative Atlantic island, denying the center-right Social Democratic Party (PSD) an absolute majority in the regional parliament for the first time since it was set up in 1976.

“This is an historical result for the Socialist Party, its best ever,” Costa told reporters. “It’s extraordinary.”

Socialist joy was muted, however, because the PSD looks likely to cling to power in Madeira by forging a coalition with the conservative CDS-People’s Party.

The PSD won 21 seats in the 47-seat assembly, down from 24, while the PS grew from five to 19. However, the three seats of the CDS-PP should be enough to form a coalition with the PSD, if the two center-right parties can overcome a history of rancor on the island.

“If what happened in Madeira today is repeated on the mainland, that would suit me just fine,” chuckled the PSD’s national leader Rui Rio as the result was confirmed.

That looks unlikely.

Latest polls have Costa’s Socialists winning close to 40 percent of the vote in the October 6 national ballot, compared to around 25 percent for the PSD.

Unless there’s a major turnaround, Europe’s most successful Socialist looks sure to again buck the trend of declining center-left fortunes elsewhere on the continent.

Voters are pleased with how Costa and Finance Minister Mário Centeno have managed the past four years of economic recovery. They still blame the center right for austerity measures introduced in return for a €78 billion bailout from the European Union and International Monetary Fund that kept finances afloat after the country was clobbered by the eurozone debt crisis.

The only real electoral suspense is whether Costa can secure an absolute majority or be obliged to continue his geringonça (contraption) alliance with two smaller, far-left parties.

Both his partners fared badly in Madeira. The Left Bloc lost its two seats in the regional assembly and the Portuguese Communist Party kept just one after seeing its vote drop from 5.5 percent to 1.8 percent.

Nationwide, however, the leftists' vote seems to be holding up better. The Left Bloc is polling around 10 percent and the PCP close to 7 percent. Both have warned that giving the Socialists an absolute majority will hand Costa excessive power and tempt the PS to lurch further to the center, away from “progressive” policies.

With Portuguese voters continuing to reject right-wing populism (two hard-right parties running in Madeira scored a combined total of 0.61 percent), the main insurgent party is the animal rights outfit People Animals and Nature (PAN).

It failed to make a breakthrough in Madeira but got its first MEP in May’s European Parliament election and is polling over 4 percent nationwide with a program that includes creating a “sort of national health service" for pets, a ban on bullfighting and setting up a network of “pet-friendly” beaches.

“They’ll wipe out our economy, wipe out investment and everybody will be forced to live like beggars like in Venezuela” — Miguel Albuquerque, outgoing presidentof Madeira

Despite such ideas, debates have been rather tepid.

A Costa vs. Rio face-off carried live during primetime on all three main national TV networks last week focused on technical points of tax policy and healthcare spending. It was completely lacking in the personal attacks and populist fireworks that have become familiar in much of Europe.

They notably agreed to make the fight against climate change a cross-party national priority. “We all have to be together on this, right and left,” Rio said. “It’s too serious to be the PSD against the PS, I even agree with the Left Bloc’s slogan: there is no planet B.”

The Madeira campaign, in contrast, was a no-holds-barred affair as the right struggled to defend its stronghold on the sub-tropical vacation island.

Lying in the Atlantic, some 500 kilometers off the coast of northwest Africa and 1,000 kilometers southwest of mainland Portugal, the autonomous region consists of Madeira island, its much smaller neighbor Porto Santo and a scattering of uninhabited rocks. It has enjoyed a wide degree of self-rule since the 1970s. Portugal’s other Atlantic archipelago, the Azores, have a similar status.

PSD leaders on the island warned a victory for the left would lead to communist-style economic ruin and unrest.

“They’ll wipe out our economy, wipe out investment and everybody will be forced to live like beggars like in Venezuela,” Miguel Albuquerque, the outgoing regional president, cautioned in a final rally. “If they want Venezuela, they should go and live there.”

That message resonated with a significant section of the population.

Tens of thousands of Madeiran islanders emigrated to Venezuela during the country’s mid-20th century oil boom. Recently, their descendants have been flocking back to escape the economic ruin and political chaos under the left-wing regime of Nicolás Maduro.

“Socialism and communism aren’t exactly the most popular words in our dictionary,” Ana Cristina Monteiro, president of the Venezuelan Immigrant Community Association, told the SAPO24 news site last week. She was elected on the CDS-PP list.

Venezuelan-Portuguese voters accounted for around 5,000 of the 258,000 registered voters in the Madeira election and the PSD’s margin of victory over the Socialists was just over 5,200 votes.
description: Polls show Socialists on course for four more years.
